Award.AwardTitle: Indirect Bridge Health Monitoring Using Moving Vehicles

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to provide accurate, rapid, nearly continuous, and cost-effective assessments of a large population of bridges using the data collected from a set of vehicles equipped with sensors able to capture the dynamic interaction between the vehicles and the bridge. This grant provides funding for the development of a new approach for assessing the health of bridges that uses vehicles with on-board sensors to collect condition information about the bridges over which they travel. The dynamic characteristics of the bridge are affected by the damage in the form of cracks, corrosion, and frozen bearings. The first premise of this research is that these changes will be detectable from the dynamic responses collected from a large number of vehicles travelling over the bridge. A second premise is that the type, location and extent of the damage on the bridge will be classified. The new approach will use multiresolution (MR) signal processing and pattern recognition algorithms to detect and classify bridge damage.

If successful, the results of this research will be beneficial to bridge authorities by leading to the development of a new indirect assessment method for monitoring the health of a large number of bridges using the same instrumented vehicles. The method will have a significant economic impact by providing an efficient and more cost effective method to improve the management of the overall structural condition of bridges. The results of this research will also lead to new signal-processing algorithms that will capture signals collected from vehicles. In addition, knowledge gained during the project will be useful for determining the applicability of this approach to different types of structures. The experience and the insights provided by this research project, which will directly involve two PhD graduate students and a number of undergraduate students, will be transferred in courses and demonstrations both at Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Pittsburgh.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As our national infrastructure ages, decision makers need accurate and reliable information on the state of each structure. This information can ensure public safety with limited resources while facilitating more efficient maintenance programs and more effective capital replacement projects. While significant progress has already been made in the field of structural health monitoring, there exist few proven practical technologies, often requiring capital-intensive installation processes, and time-consuming maintenance programs. Instead of placing sensors on the infrastructure itself (at enormous cost), in this project we explored placing sensors on vehicles that happen to be using the infrastructure already, in order to identify damage in the infrastructure. Such sensors can be shielded from the harsh environment, provided power more readily, and make a single vehicle capable of monitoring thousands of kilometers of roads or rails as it travels.

This project had three distinct phases: computer simulations to test the validity of the approach, laboratory-scale experiments, and finally a full-scale deployment on an operational transit system.

In the first phase, we started with a one-dimensional model of a vehicle moving over a bridge structure. The goal was to see how the dynamic response of the vehicle would change as we simulated damage in the bridge structure. By using multi-resolution classification on the simulated data, we verified that we were able to detect structural changes in the simulated bridge. 

In the second phase, we built a 10m long physical model of a bridge, complete with an instrumented vehicle that could drive back and forth over the structure. We determined our ability to detect numerous types of changes in the structure including changes in mass, stiffness, damping, and support conditions under a variety of temperature scenarios.

In the final phase, we collaborated with the Port Authority of Allegheny County to instrument two of their Light Rail Vehicles. We placed accelerometers inside the train, on the wheel axle, and a GPS module on the roof, and we developed an identification and classification methodology based on the analysis of the signals recorded in the moving vehicle to determine changes in the system. We have been able to observe how the dynamic response of the vehicle over a particular section of track changes over time. Most recently, we have been able to detect subtle changes in the track from sensors in the cabin of an operational train. While thus far we have applied successfully our detection methodology to the track system, this methodology is general, and can be applied to other parts of the system, including bridges.

Over this four-year project, we have taken a simple idea—to monitor infrastructure assets with the very vehicle that uses them—and explored it both theoretically and experimentally. Although the development of this technology is far from over, this project has already allowed us to move the technology from its infancy to an operational system. This type of indirect monitoring is a low-cost solution with the potential to make infrastructure safer and more economical to operate.
